Chart.Topic: Population by marital status in Iceland from 2013 to 2023, by main categories
Chart.Description: From 2013 to 2023, the number of married individuals living with their spouse in Iceland increased from approximately 105,000 to over 121,000. Within the same years, the number of unmarried singles also increased, from over 81,000 in 2013 to 90,000 in 2023. Similarly, the numbers of divorced singles increased, from 17,000 in 2013 to 21,000 in 2023.

Chart.Topic: Number of Italian nationals resident in London (UK) from 2015 to 2020
Chart.Description:
As of 2020, 131 thousand Italians were living in London. From 2015 to 2017, the number of Italian citizens who lived in the English Capital increased steadily. However, the Italian population living in London fell between 2018 and 2019. Nonetheless, the United Kingdom is the most popular destination country among Italian emigrants. During 2019, about 19 percent of all Italians who moved abroad notably chose the United Kingdom.

Student migration
The United Kingdom is a very common destination among young Italians in particular. In addition, a large percentage of emigrants who moved to the United Kingdom achieved a higher education. Specifically, 31 percent of Italians who live in the United Kingdom hold a university degree. However, the countries with most Italian emigrants holding a are Brazil, Ireland, and the United States.

Currently, Argentina has the largest . , Argentina was one of the most important destinations of Italian emigrants, especially during the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. Currently, Argentina ranks only tenth among the main destination countries of Italians. The most common destinations are, together with the United Kingdom, Germany and France.

Chart.Topic: Urban population in Thailand from 2011 to 2023
Chart.Description: In 2023, the urban population in Thailand stood at approximately 38.5 million, which was an increase compared to the previous year. The figures show a gradual increase in the urban population throughout the years.

Chart.Topic: Population of Belgium in 2023, by age group
Chart.Description: In 2023, approximately 799,500 people in Belgium were aged between 55 and 59, and roughly 102,200 people were aged between 90 and 94. The largest age group was formed by those between 55 and 59 years old, whereas those over 100 years old formed the smallest age group. In 2023, approximately 2,700 people in Belgium were 100 years or older.

Chart.Topic: Population of Belgium in 2023, by age and gender
Chart.Description: In 2023, Belgium counted just over one million male residents over 65 years old, while the number of female residents of this age group reached over 1.28 million. In that year, the majority of the population, both male and female, was between the ages of 18 and 64 years old.

Chart.Topic: Mortality rate in Romania in 2021, by main causes of death and by gender

Characteristic: Traumatic injuries, poisonings and other consequences of external causes

Chart.Description: The main causes of death in Romania in 2021 were diseases of the circulatory system, followed by tumors. Men had a higher mortality rate for tumors, digestive tract diseases and traumatic injuries compared to women.

Chart.Topic: Number of foreign citizens living in South Korea in 2023, by country of origin and gender
Chart.Description: In 2023, South Korea had about 532,000 registered Chinese nationals of Korean heritage. This was followed by foreign nationals from Vietnam and China with around 247,000 and 221,000, respectively. Overall, the proportion of men with foreign citizenship was higher than that of women.

Chart.Topic: Labor force aged 15 years and above in Singapore from June 2013 to June 2022
Chart.Description: As of June 2022, the working age labor force in Singapore amounted to approximately 3.75 million people. In that year, Singapore's labor force participation rate was at 70 percent.

Chart.Topic: Number of LinkedIn users in the Netherlands from 2013 to 2023
Chart.Description:
The number of LinkedIn users in the Netherlands has remained stable at approximately five million people since 2021. Among Millennials, LinkedIn was among the more popular social media platforms in the country.

LinkedIn had the highest reach on smartphone
LinkedIn had an online reach (the percentage of visitors that visited specific content at least once during a certain period) of 27.2 percent in the Netherlands in January 2019. This is a decrease when compared to the same period one year before. The highest reach was on smartphone: 16.2 percent or roughly 2.6 million devices.

LinkedIn was considered in the Netherlands. Approximately eight percent of survey participants thought that LinkedIn posts were trustworthy, whereas 40 percent distrusted them. Compared to other social media, however, there were more respondents who had a neutral viewpoint or no opinion at all.

Chart.Topic: Share of Western Europe's population living in the five Mediterranean countries of France, Greece, Italy, Portugal, and Spain in selected years between 0 and 1998
Chart.Description: At the beginning of the Common Era, over three quarters of Western Europe's population lived in the Mediterranean regions that make up present-day France, Greece, Italy, Spain, and Portugal. At this time, all of these areas were under the control of the Roman Empire, and remained so until the fifth century. The Mediterranean region was the center of trade between Europe, Asia, and Africa throughout most of Antiquity and the Middle Ages, and many of the most populous cities in the Europe were located in present-day Italy or Spain during this time. Due to this fact, these metropolitan areas were some of the most severely-hit during pandemic outbreaks. The emergence of Europe's maritime empires during the 16th and 17th centuries, and later the economic growth of Germany, led to a shift in Western Europe's population distribution; yet, over half of the population was located in these Mediterranean countries until the 19 century.

Chart.Topic: Age dependency ratio in Mexico from 1980 to 2023
Chart.Description: In 2023, the age dependency ratio in Mexico amounted to around 48.38 percent. This was a slight decrease from the previous year. Overall, the age dependency ratio in the country has been steadily decreasing since the year 1980.

Chart.Topic: Number of internet users in Singapore 2011-2029
Chart.Description:
The number of internet users in Singapore was forecast to continuously increase between 2024 and 2029 by in total 0.2 million users (+3.37 percent). After the seventh consecutive increasing year, the number of users is estimated to reach 6.1 million users and therefore a new peak in 2029.
Depicted is the estimated number of individuals in the country or region at hand, that use the internet. As the datasource clarifies, connection quality and usage frequency are distinct aspects, not taken into account here.The shown data are an excerpt of Statista's Key Market Indicators (KMI). The KMI are a collection of primary and secondary indicators on the macro-economic, demographic and technological environment in up to 150 countries and regions worldwide. All indicators are sourced from international and national statistical offices, trade associations and the trade press and they are processed to generate comparable data sets (see supplementary notes under details for more information).

Find further information concerning and .

Chart.Topic: Unemployment rate by gender in Rio de Janeiro from the 2nd quarter of 2022 to 2nd quarter of 2024
Chart.Description: In the second quarter of 2024, approximately nine percent of Rio de Janeiro's workforce was unemployed. Women in the workforce had a higher unemployment rate than men, however, the female unemployment rate saw a decrease between the first quarter of 2023 and the second quarter of 2024. Rio de Janeiro's unemployment rate in Q2 of 2024 was slightly higher when compared to the monthly national average.

Chart.Topic: Share of the population living in poverty by race and Hispanic origin in the United States from 1959 to 2022
Chart.Description:
In the U.S., the share of the population living in poverty fluctuated significantly throughout the six decades between 1987 and 2022. In 2022, the poverty level across all races and ethnicities was 11.5 percent. Historically, whites generally had the lowest poverty rates. However the poverty rate among Asian Americans was below that of whites in most years of the 2010s.

In contrast, Black Americans were the ethnic group with the highest share of their population living in poverty in almost every year since 1974. In 1979 alone, Black poverty was well over double the national average, and over four times the poverty rate in white communities; in 1982, almost 48 percent of the Black population lived in poverty. Although poverty rates have been trending downward across all ethnic groups, 17 percent of Black Americans and 20 percent of American Indian and Alaskan Natives still lived below the poverty line in 2022.

Chart.Topic: Share of the immigrant population in France from 1921 to 2022
Chart.Description: This graph represents the share of the immigrant population in France from 1921 to 2022. The statistic reveals that the share of immigrants in France had slightly increased since 1921. There were 6.6 percent of immigrants in 1931 compare to 10.3 percent in 2022.

Chart.Topic: Population density of Finland in 2023, by region
Chart.Description: In 2023, the population density of Finland was 18.4 inhabitants per square kilometer. The most densely populated region was Uusimaa with approximately 193.2 inhabitants per square kilometer. Lapland was the most scarcely populated region with roughly two inhabitants per square kilometer.

Chart.Topic: Installed coal power generation capacity worldwide from 2005 to 2022, with a forecast until 2050
Chart.Description: Installed coal power generation capacity has increased worldwide, almost doubling between 2005 and 2022, when it amounted to roughly 2.27 terawatts. Figures are expected to remain relatively stable, and reach 2.28 terawatts by 2050.

Chart.Topic: Total worldwide adherents of largest world religions and faiths in 2010 and projected adherents in 2050
Chart.Description: As of 2010, Christianity was the religion with the most followers worldwide, followed by Islam (Muslims) and Hinduism. In the forty years between 2010 and 2050, it is projected that the landscape of world religions will undergo some noticeable changes, with the number of Muslims almost catching up to Christians. The changes in population sizes of each religious group is largely dependent on demographic development, for example, the rise in the world's Christian population will largely be driven by population growth in Sub-Saharan Africa, while Muslim populations will rise across various regions of Africa and South Asia. As India's population is set to grow while China's goes into decline, this will be reflected in the fact that Hindus will outnumber the unaffiliated by 2050. In fact, India may be home to both the largest Hindu and Muslim populations in the world by the middle of this century.

Chart.Topic: Number of United States citizens living in South Korea from 2015 to 2023
Chart.Description: In 2022, about 48 thousand U.S. citizens lived in South Korea, down from about 58.2 thousand in the previous year. During the examined period, 2019 saw the highest number of U.S. citizens living in South Korea, standing at around 78.5 thousand.

Chart.Topic: Population distribution in Germany as of December 31, 2023, by age group and gender
Chart.Description:
As of December 2023, approximately 27.1 percent of men and 26.5 percent of women in Germany were aged between 40 and 59 years. 

In this statistic, gender distribution is shown based on relevant age groups. This includes infants (under one year), toddlers and preschoolers (1-5 years old), school-aged children (6-13 years old) and adolescents (14-17 years old). Please note that there are various possible options to define and categorize age groups.

Chart.Topic: Child population as a share of total population in South Africa in 2018, by age group
Chart.Description: As of 2018, 34.5 percent of the South African population were children aged 17 years and younger. Of those, the majority were in the youngest age group of six years and younger. Moreover, children between seven and 13 years represented 13.4 percent of the total population.

Chart.Topic: Household structures in Italy in 2023

Characteristic: Households with two or more nucleus

Chart.Description: In Italy, households without a nucleus represented around 37 percent of all households in 2023. Households without a nucleus are people living alone, families composed of, e.g., two sisters, a parent living with a separated, widow or divorced child, etc. On the other hand, around 30 percent of all households in the country were couples with children.

Chart.Topic: Population of Spain from 1800 to 2020
Chart.Description:
In 1800, the population of Spain was approximately 14.7 million. This figure would rise consistently throughout the 19th century, and early 20th century. The population growth rate was set to increase in the mid-1900s, but this was interrupted by the Spanish Civil War, which would claim around half a million lives between 1936 and 1939. In spite of the war, the Spanish population continued to grow throughout these years, and reached 28 million by the middle of the century. Between the 1950s and 1970s, Spain observed a significant increase in its population growth, facilitated by the baby boom that followed the Second World War (as in most of Western Europe) as well as general medical improvements and increased life expectancy.

Beginning in the 1980s, Spain would begin a demographic transition marked by a , resulting in the population only growing by two million between the mid-1980s and 2000 (compared to an increase of two million every five or six years beforehand). There was a sharp rise in Spain’s population from 2000 to 2008, as strong economic growth would be accompanied by a dramatic surge in immigration to the country. This would plateau at just over 46 million in 2008 however, as the Great Recession took its toll on the country’s economy, and in 2020, Spain is estimated to have a population of approximately 46.8 million, which is the .

Chart.Topic: Most popular social networks in the Netherlands as of April 2024, by share of visits
Chart.Description: As of April 2024, Facebook accounted for over 72 percent of all social media visits in the Netherlands. Overall, Instagram held a share of 11.34 percent of social network visits in the country, followed by Pinterest with 7.1 percent. Furthermore, professional online network LinkedIn accounted for 1.05 percent of all social media visits in the Netherlands.

Chart.Topic: Most popular social networks in Luxembourg as of April 2024, by share of visits
Chart.Description: As of April 2024, Facebook accounted for over 62 percent of all social media visits in Luxembourg. Overall, Instagram held a share of 11.9 percent of social network visits in the country, followed by X/Twitter with 10.43 percent. Furthermore, professional online network LinkedIn accounted for 0.82 percent of all social media visits in Luxembourg.

Chart.Topic: Most popular social networks in Belgium as of April 2024, by share of visits
Chart.Description: Facebook was the social network with the largest market share in Belgium as of April 2024. The market share of Facebook made up 67.13 percent of the total market in the country. Overall, Instagram reached 12.1 percent, ranking second. Additionally, Pinterest had roughly 10.54 percent of all social network visits in Belgium.

Chart.Topic: Number of immigrants to Sweden in 2023, by age group
Chart.Description: In 2023, immigrants aged 25 to 34 years formed the biggest group in Sweden with nearly 30,000 people. The second biggest group of immigrants was people aged 35 to 44, closely followed by the age group 15 to 24. A total of 102,000 immigrants arrived in Sweden in 2022.

Chart.Topic: Share of foreigners in Luxembourg from 2009 to 2023
Chart.Description: This statistic displays the share of foreigners in Luxembourg from 2009 to 2023. In 2023, 47.4 percent of the total population were foreigners, an increase of 0.3 percentage points compared to the previous year.

Chart.Topic: Vietnam: Age structure from 2012 to 2022
Chart.Description: This statistic shows the age structure in Vietnam from 2012 to 2022. In 2022, about 22.39 percent of Vietnam's total population were aged 0 to 14 years.

Chart.Topic: Population of Philippines from 1800 to 2020
Chart.Description: In 1800, the population of the islands which make up the territory of the Philippines had a population of approximately 1.89 million. The population of the archipelago would grow steadily throughout the 19th century, reaching almost 6.5 million people by 1900. However, the population would begin to rise much more rapidly following the country’s independence from the United States in 1946, as post-war economic aid from the United States and expansive modernization projects by the Philippine government would lead to a significant rise in standards of living and result in a post-war baby boom. This growth would remain steady well into the 21st century, and while the rate of population growth has fallen somewhat in recent years, the population of the Philippines is expected to continue its increase in the coming years, and in 2020, the Philippines is estimated to have a population of just under 110 million, which is almost twelve times larger than the Philippines' population in 1920.

Chart.Topic: Kenya: Inflation rate from 1987 to 2029
Chart.Description:
In 2018, the average inflation rate in Kenya amounted to about 4.69 percent compared to the previous year, a significant decrease from 7.99 percent the year prior. Forecasts see Kenya’s inflation levelling off at around five percent in the near future.

Kenya sees economic growth

Kenya’s economic growth has been quite steady these past few years and is still on the rise – except for a little dip in 2017, which is no real reason for concern. Gross domestic product (GDP) is forecast to almost double by 2024, and , although still above 10 percent, is on the decline. Although Kenya may not be among the leading countries on the yet, but these economic trends plus demographic key factors like a declining and a that has increased by a decade over the same time span show that Kenya is definitely on the way.



Kenya’s market-based economy is considered East Africa’s finance and transportation hub. Most of Kenya’s GDP is generated by , especially travel and tourism, but agriculture is also quite successful, as it contributes about a third to GDP. The country exports less than it imports, and its leading exports are mostly commodities like tea and coffee. Imports include petroleum, machinery, and metals. Subsequently, Kenya’s trade balance is in the red, however, is decreasing.

Chart.Topic: Population forecast of Finland from 2021 to 2040
Chart.Description: According to the forecast, the total population of Finland is expected to grow until 2035 and decline after that. The forecast shows that by 2035 the population is estimated to be 5.6 million inhabitants. Thereafter, the population is expected to decrease to 5.59 million inhabitants by 2040.

Chart.Topic: Main languages spoken at home in Tunisia as of 2022
Chart.Description: According to a survey conducted in 2021, Tunisian Arabic was the main language spoken in around 93 percent of households in Tunisia. Arabic followed, with by roughly 6 percent of Tunisians. Berber language accounted for only 0.1 percent, according to the survey.

Chart.Topic: Number of live births after Poland's accession to the European Union (EU) from 2004 to 2023
Chart.Description: The number of live births in Poland reached over 272 thousand in 2023 and decreased by nearly 24 percent compared to 2004.

Chart.Topic: Population of Venezuela from 1810 to 2020
Chart.Description:
In 1810, the region of present-day Venezuela had a population of approximately 720,000 people. Despite beginning this period with a war of independence and spending much of the latter half of the 19th century embroiled in several civil wars, the population of Venezuela would continue to increase steadily in this century, reaching the three million mark in 1910.
Oil boom
From the late 1910s onwards, Venezuela's economic and demographic development would become inextricably linked to its booming oil industry. By the 1930s, Venezuela had become the world's largest exporter of oil; although it was overtaken by the U.S. and Soviet Union following the Second World War, Venezuela was a founding member of , and . This boom resulted in a large wave of migration from Europe and other regions of the Americas, as well as economic investment and influence from the U.S. government and the "seven sisters" oil companies. The Colombian crisis of the late 20 century also resulted in a wave of mass migration to Venezuela, which began in the 1980s; by the early 2000s it was estimated that displaced Colombians constituted one seventh of the total Venezuelan population.

Venezuela's population growth continued into the 21 century, and by 2015, the population would peak at just over thirty million people. In the past five years, however, it is estimated that Venezuela's population has dropped by over 1.5 million (or five percent). The reason for this decline can be traced back to the economic mismanagement and radical leftist policies of Hugo Chávez; the first half of Chávez's term was characterized socioeconomic progress that improved the healthcare system and quality of life of most Venezuelans, however, the second half saw his regime become increasingly authoritarian and oppressive, and economically unsustainable. Chávez died in 2013, but his successor, Nicolás Maduro, continued upon the trajectory of the Chávez administration, which led to mass protests, and, eventually, one of the most severe humanitarian crises in the world. Some estimates suggest that the weight of the average Venezuelan had , and that ninety percent of the population was living in poverty by 2018. As of 2019, , and this number is expected to rise above six million in the next year. As the crisis continues, Venezuelan population has continued to fall, and in 2020, it is estimated that approximately 28.4 million people live in the country.

Chart.Topic: Population of South Africa in 2022, by age group and gender
Chart.Description: As of 2022, children between 10 and 14 years (over 5.7 million people) represented the largest share of the total South African population. In this age group, there were almost 66,000 more boys than girls. Moreover, in all the age groups between zero and 39 years, the number of men was higher than that of women. However, among South Africans aged 40 or older, the count of women in the population was greater than that of men.

Chart.Topic: Daily time spent using the internet among online users in the United States as of 3rd quarter 2023, by device
Chart.Description: During the third quarter of 2023, online users in the United States spent over seven hours daily using the internet. Of this, three hours and 39 minutes were via mobile phones. Mobile phones accounts for over half of online minutes in the United States.

Chart.Topic: Number of people living in extreme poverty in Ghana from 2016 to 2026, by gender
Chart.Description: In 2024, an estimated 6.9 million people in Ghana lived in extreme poverty, the majority being the male population. The number of men in the country living on less than 2.15 U.S. dollars a day reached around 3.5 million, while the count was at 3.3 million for women. Overall, 1.1 percent of the global population in extreme poverty was found in Ghana as of 2024.

Chart.Topic: Number of people living in extreme poverty in Ghana from 2016 to 2026
Chart.Description:
As of 2024, some 6.9 million people in Ghana lived in extreme poverty, with the poverty threshold at 2.15 U.S. dollars per day. This stood as an increase from the previous year when roughly 6.8 million people lived in the said state of poverty. In 2026, around 6.7 million Ghanaians are expected to live on a maximum of 2.15 U.S. dollars daily.

Poverty in the country is segregated
Indeed, poverty figures do not considerably vary when considering men and women apart. In 2024, around 3.5 million men lived in extreme poverty in Ghana, while the count reached roughly 3.3 million for women. On the other hand, in distinguishing the , the difference is striking, even when based on the previously set poverty line of 1.90 U.S. dollars per day. Chart.Topic: Population forecast of Finland from 2020 and 2070, by gender
Chart.Description: According to the forecast, the population of Finland is expected to grow until 2030. The number of men is estimated to grow slightly faster than the number of women in Finland, and by 2045, the number of male and female inhabitants is expected to be roughly the same. Thereafter, the number of men is estimated to exceed the number of women. By 2070, there is expected to be 2.63 million male and 2.55 million female inhabitants.
